Sysco Cincinnati, LLC Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

We at Sysco Cincinnati, LLC are committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate control measures to prevent possible releases of Ammonia (anhydrous).  Unforseeable, if such a release does occur, our highly trained employees are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  We are also completely coordinated with the Evendale Fire Department, who provides our off-site emergency response services.

2.  The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled:

We have one regulated substance present at our facility.  That substance is Ammonia (anhydrous).  The maximum inventory of Ammonia (anhydrous) that is expected to be present in this facility, based on process/operational requirements, is 12,000 pounds.

3.  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Our facility has taken the following steps as required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the Clean Air Act.  Our Ammonia (anhydrous) process is subject to the OSHA PSM Standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  Our facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 reporting requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the accidental release prevention program that is in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information:

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our process are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is the What-If Checklist.  The studies are conducted by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineer

ing and process operations and maintenance and are revalidated a a regular interval of every 5 years.  Any findings related to the hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readiliy accessible to operators and maintenance personnel involved in the process.

Training:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating and maintaining processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  New employees receive basic classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided at least annually and more frequently if needed.

Mechanical Integrity:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC conducts highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation.  Process equipment examined during these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Qualified personnel conduct maintenance operations with special training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are given specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified during the maintenance checks are corrected in a timely manner.

Management of Change:

Written procedures are in place at Sysco Cincinnati, LLC to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and processes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification to  process operations, are promptly made aware of, and giv

en, information and training to safely manage the modification.

Pre-Startup Reviews:

Pre-startup reviews related to new processes, and to modifications of established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Sysco Cincinnati, LLC.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for a safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions required by the RMP regulation are being implemented.  These audits are completed at least every three years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are completed in a timely manner.

Incident Investigation:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC promptly investigated any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  These investigations are conducted to identify the circumstances leading up to the incident, as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release or near-miss from recurring.  All accident/incident reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC believes that process safety management and accident prevention required a team effort.  Company and contractor employees are urged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements for the ammonia refrigeration system.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP regulation, including information resulting from process hazard analyses, in particular.

Contractors:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is completed.  Sysco Cincinnati, LLC has a strict policy of informing contractors of known and

potential hazards releated to the contractor's work and the process.  Contractors are also informed of all of the procedures for the emergency notification, evacuation and the accountability of personnel, should an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous) occur.

4.  5-Year Accident History:

There have been no reportable accidents or incidents at this facility during the past 5 years.

5.  Emergency Response Plan:

Sysco Cincinnati, LLC is included in the written community emergency response plan.  The facility also has an emergency response plan.  The emergency response plan includes specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous) and includes procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies in the event of an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous).  The emergency response plan also includes information on emergency health care.

The date of the most recent review/update of the emergency response plan is: October 6, 2011 

The date of the most recent emergency response plan training of employees is: September 19, 2011

The local agency coordinating the facility emergency response plan is the Evendale Fire Department, which has a phone number of: 513-563-2248.

6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program.  We will continue our annual facility emergency notification, evacuation and accountability training and drills.  All visitors, vendors, contractors and employees sign or check in and out of our facility.  In addition, they all receive emergency notification, evacuation and accountability training, or are the responsibility of another Sysco employee when they enter the facility.
